In 2002, Grant was appointed to the Senior Executive Service and assigned as the first civilian director, resources and analysis, for U.S. operations in the Middle East, Central and South Asia and North East Africa. Working with senior representatives from 65 countries, she led resource strategy and analysis for operations Iraqi Freedom and Enduring Freedom.

She later helped establish U.S. Africa Command as its first director of resources, leading personnel and financial programming that served as the foundation for successful interagency and international partnerships for global security.

From 2010 through 2018, Grant served as deputy under secretary of the Air Force, International Affairs, providing oversight and guidance for international policy and for programs supporting global national security objectives; technology and information disclosure; security assistance; education and training; and cooperative research and development. She also managed the Air Force Foreign Liaison Office and attaché affairs.

Grant holds a Master of Public Administration in financial management from Troy State University and a Bachelor of Science in business from Pfeiffer University. She is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations.

name: Dr. John Edgar Caterson
title: U.S. Special Operations Command SOCH ESME, SOCH Program Director
bio:
Dr. John Edgar Catterson serves as the SOCOM SOCH Joint Special Operations University Executive Subject Matter Expert (ESME) and as the Program Director for the Special Operations Chaplains Advanced Courses Program (SOCAC), as well as the Master SOF Instructor of Record for the SOF Ethical Leadership Advisement, the Spiritual & Moral Resiliency, Special Operations Crisis Care and Counseling, and Religious Support Team Orientation.

A graduate of Princeton Theological Seminary, The University of Edinburgh in Scotland, and The Beeson International Center at Asbury Theological Seminary, he holds a Bachelor of Arts in Philosophy & Religion, a Master of Divinity with a concentration in ethics, was a Supervised Post-Graduate Fellow in Ethics & Leadership, and earned a Doctorate degree with concentrations in Story Integration, Narrative Theology, Leadership & Ethics, and Psychology.

name: Sergeant Major (Ret.) Mike Vining
title: Director, National EOD Association
bio:
Sergeant Major (Ret.) Mike Vining is a director and assistant historian for the National Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Association and conducts historical EOD research for the EOD Warrior Foundation.

He served in the United States Army 1st Special Forces Operational Detachment - Delta and Joint Special Operations Command, retiring from active duty as a sergeant major in 1999. He attended the first Operator Training Course (OTC-1) and served as an Operator, EOD, Master Breacher, R&D SGM, and Breach R&D SGM.

In Special Forces, he served in the 10th Group, 1st Group, SWC at the Noncommissioned Officers Academy, and in the 3rd Group. He has held the positions of communications sergeant, senior communications sergeant, senior small group leader, team sergeant, and advanced skills company committee chief.

Mr. Clark graduated from Campbell University in Buies Creek, North Carolina, in 2006, earning a Bachelor of Science in History. He then graduated from Webster University in St. Louis, Missouri, in 2007, earning a Master of Arts in Human Resource Development.

name: Master Sergeant (Ret.) Mike Clark
title: Course Manager, College of SO/LIC
bio:
Master Sergeant (Ret.) Michael W. Clark II is a faculty member in the College of Special Operations & Low-Intensity Conflict at the Joint Special Operations University. He served in the United States Army Special Forces, retiring from active duty as a master sergeant in 2014.

In Special Forces, he served in 10th Grp, 1st Grp, SWC at the Noncommissioned Officers Academy, and in 3rd Grp. He has held the positions of communications sergeant, senior communications sergeant, senior small group leader, team sergeant, and advanced skills company committee chief.

Mr. Clark graduated from Campbell University in Buies Creek, North Carolina, in 2006, earning a Bachelor of Science in history. He graduated from Webster University in St. Louis, Missouri, in 2007, earning a Master of Arts in human resource development.

name: Petty Officer First Class (Ret.) Mike Kipp
title: The Veterans Project
bio:
Mike served for eleven years in the US Navy Special Forces. During his time in the military, he performed a number of highly classified missions around the world. Prior to suffering serious injuries that forced an early departure from the military, Mike did three years in Vietnam, helped rescue a group of children from a slave operation out of Mexico, assisted in stopping the drug trade coming out of Colombia, trained a number of Special Forces groups from various countries including Korea, the Philippines, South Vietnam, and the Shah of Iran's Royal Guard. He led operations into North Korea, Ukraine, and Czechoslovakia. His service includes working with Israel, Germany, England, Spain, France, and other Allied countries.

Mike's time in the military and during his civilian career has allowed him to perform operations for Presidents Nixon, Ford, and Clinton. On several occasions, he has led operations and briefed members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, members of the US Congress and Senate, as well as dignitaries from a number of different countries.

Currently, Mike sits on several veterans' boards and works to help veterans whenever and wherever he can. He was honored by five different veterans' associations for his untiring voluntary service. Mike assists with veterans' suicide prevention, Special Forces Associations, and is working to change legislation that would help improve disabled veterans' quality of life.

In addition, Mike consults with the Haitian government in helping to resolve the violence that is currently overwhelming the country, as well as assisting in the planning for the rebuilding of the country after a number of devastating earthquakes, gang violence, hurricanes, and other natural disasters.

Over his career, Mike has received a number of awards, degrees, and decorations.

name: Dr. Anna Simons
title: Professor Emerita
bio:
Anna Simons is a Professor Emerita of Defense Analysis at the Naval Postgraduate School. She taught there from 1999-2019, after six years as an assistant and then associate professor of anthropology at UCLA.

She has written several books and multiple monographs, and has overseen projects for offices within the Office of the Secretary of Defense, as well as for several different military commands. As a member of the DA Department, Anna happily taught courses in the anthropology of conflict, military advising, low-intensity conflict in Africa, political anthropology, and comparative SOF. She also ran six iterations of the Long-Term Strategy Seminar sponsored by the Office of Net Assessment.

Once upon a time, she attended Harvard, briefly worked as a journalist, then as a presidential speechwriter, spent multiple years as a vagabond (predominantly in Africa and Israel), accidentally went back to Harvard for her PhD, and even more accidentally ended up in Somalia for her dissertation fieldwork. Way back when, she had hoped to live with camel nomads. She now lives in Montana among cattle ranchers.

name: Sergeant Major Adam Thompson
title: Commandant
company: Joint Special Operations Forces Senior Enlisted Academy
bio:
CSM Adam Thompson is the Commandant of the Joint Special Operations Senior Enlisted Academy (JSOFSEA) at USSOCOM. JSOFSEA develops senior enlisted SOF professionals to think critically, creatively, and ethically about dynamic and complex problem sets at operational and strategic levels, creating the ultimate "Warrior-Diplomats."

CSM Thompson ensures that students gain valuable knowledge and experience to successfully lead in the joint, interagency, intergovernmental, and multinational (JIIM) environment.

CSM Thompson is a U.S. Army Green Beret with 24 years of service. His most recent assignment was serving as the Course Director for JSOFSEA CEP 3. He is a Master Training Specialist and provides perspective and direction to instructors as they administer a curriculum that is the cornerstone of success for future Senior Enlisted Leaders in the Joint SOF enterprise.

name: Ms. Catherine Herridge
title: Independent investigative journalist
bio:
Catherine V. Herridge is an Emmy Award‐winning veteran investigative correspondent who covers national security and intelligence. In February, Herridge was held in civil contempt by a US federal court for refusing to disclose her confidential sources for a series of national security reports in 2017.

As a senior investigative correspondent for CBS News from 2019-2024, Herridge’s reporting was a catalyst for legislative change affecting more than a million American veterans and civilians. The Investigative Unit’s Emmy‐nominated series “Decades of Exposure” is credited by activists and lawmakers with the passing of the Camp Lejeune Justice Act in August 2022.  Part of the burn pit legislation known as the PACT ACT, the law is considered one of the largest expansions of VA healthcare and benefits for American veterans.

In 2021, Herridge and the CBS News Investigative Unit won the Society of Environmental Journalists’ Kevin Carmody Award for Outstanding Investigative Reporting, for a year-long probe that exposed serious health hazards at the K-2 military base in Uzbekistan that supported Special Operations missions into Afghanistan after 9/11. In response to Herridge’s reporting, an Executive Order recognized K2 veterans and mandated a comprehensive Defense Department study on the health consequences.

Herridge’s recent reporting on retired Col. Paris Davis, one of the first Black officers in the elite Green Berets, kept his story in front of government decision makers and helped right a 58-year-old wrong. In March 2023, the Vietnam hero was awarded the Medal of Honor at the White House for his heroism at the 1965 Battle of Bong Son after his nomination paperwork was lost twice at the height of the civil rights movement. Race was blamed as a factor.

Herridge has reported from Afghanistan, Iraq, Qatar, Israel, Northern Ireland, Russia and the former Yugoslavia.   Prior to joining CBS News, Herridge was the chief intelligence correspondent for FOX News Channel (FNC), and a TV and radio correspondent for ABC News in London.  In 2019, the Congressional Medal of Honor Society awarded Herridge with its annual Tex McCrary Award for excellence in journalism.

She is a graduate of Harvard College and the Columbia School of Journalism where she founded a national security reporting scholarship.  Herridge comes from a military family and lives in Washington, D.C., with her husband, a West Point graduate, and their two boys.

name: His Majesty King Abdullah II ibn Al Hussein
title: King of Jordan
bio:
Born in Amman in 1962, His Majesty King Abdullah II ibn Al Hussein attended Oxford University and the School of Foreign Service at Georgetown University, received his military education at Britain’s Royal Military Academy Sandhurst and pursued a distinguished military career, rising from first lieutenant to major general and serving as commander of Jordan’s special forces. In February 1999, he ascended to the Throne of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan after the passing of his father, His Majesty King Hussein.

King Abdullah II has devoted himself to defending Jordan as an island of progress in a turbulent region. This has included investing in the immense human capital of his people, combating terrorism and extremism within a holistic approach, and working to expand peace prospects in the Middle East. 

As the 41st generation direct descendant of the Prophet Muhammad, King Abdullah II has taken the lead in advancing harmony both within Islam and among the world’s great religions. In 2004, he launched the “Amman Message,” the first major initiative by a Muslim leader to affirm that terrorism and violence have no place in Islam. In 2006, His Majesty supported and funded “A Common Word Between Us and You”, which calls for peace and harmony between Muslims and Christians. And in 2010, the United Nations General Assembly unanimously adopted his proposal for a World Interfaith Harmony Week, which has been observed annually ever since in the first week of February.

In 2015, His Majesty launched the Aqaba Process initiative to enhance regional and international coordination to counter terrorism and extremism within a holistic approach that extends to the military, security, and ideological dimensions.

In recognition of his efforts to promote peace, spread interfaith harmony, and safeguard Islamic and Christian holy sites in Jerusalem under the Hashemite Custodianship, King Abdullah II has received several prestigious awards, including the Peace of Westphalia Prize, the Templeton Prize, Italy’s Lamp of Peace of St. Francis, the Scholar-Statesman Award from the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, the Zayed Award for Human Fraternity, and the Path to Peace Award.

His Majesty is married to Her Majesty Queen Rania Al Abdullah. They have four children—two sons, Their Royal Highnesses Crown Prince Al Hussein and Prince Hashem, and two daughters, Their Royal Highnesses Princess Iman and Princess Salma.

name: Mr. Larry Royer, LCSW, BCD
title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker
bio: Larry enlisted in the Army July 1992 as a Pharmacy Tech. He served 18 years Active Duty and was promoted to MSG. He then applied and was accepted into the Army MSW program and commissioned as a 2LT in October 2010. Larry spent 14 years as an LCSW and retired in July 2024. As an LCSW, served with the 101st Airborne and deployed with the Rakkasans. Larry spent 8 years in USASOC, 6 of those in 3D SFG(A) and 2 in SWCS. Larry graduated in 2003 with his Bachelors of Science, 2010 with his Masters of Healthcare Administration and in 2011 with his Masters of Social Work. He currently serves as a POTFF contractor for KBR, supporting the Military Free Fall School at Yuma Proving Grounds and the Directorate of Psychological Applications at Ft Bragg. Larry is married to Vivian of 17 year and they have 4 beautiful children and 1 grandson.

name: Ms. Jodi Burns
title: Chief Executive Officer
bio:
Jodi Burns is a dedicated advocate for the Special Forces community, serving as the CEO of the Special Forces Charitable Trust. With decades of experience supporting military families, she has committed her life to ensuring Green Berets and their loved ones receive the care and resources they deserve. 

Before leading the Trust, Jodi spent over 11 years developing and directing a BUMED funded program with the Center for Military Relationships & Family, focused on strengthening the Special Operations community. Through this work, she built deep connections and developed programs addressing the unique challenges faced by SOF families. She brought that experience to the Trust, expanding its impact and ensuring critical support reaches those who need it most. 

As the wife of a U.S. Navy SEAL for 28 years, Jodi has personally endured the trials of military life—raising children through more than 12 combat deployments and navigating the sacrifices that come with service. Her firsthand experience fuels her passion for advocating for SOF families, ensuring they receive support that is both immediate and lasting. 

Under Jodi’s leadership, the Special Forces Charitable Trust continues to grow, offering essential programs that strengthen families, provide emergency aid, and promote long-term wellness. She is a champion for those who stand behind America’s elite warriors, ensuring they are never forgotten.

name: Ms. Kerry Irvin
title: Chief Executive Officer
bio:
With a strong background in nonprofit development and executive leadership, Kerry has a proven record of strategically growing sustainable, impactful organizations. As a veteran spouse deeply connected to the Special Operations Forces (SOF) community—and as the daughter, wife, and mother of U.S. Service Members—she brings a personal understanding of the sacrifices and challenges faced by military families.

Now leading Operation Healing Forces (OHF) into its next phase of growth, Kerry is committed to building strategic partnerships nationwide to expand OHF’s programs and capacity. Her vision is to strengthen OHF’s ability to support SOF service members, their families, and caregivers with vital resources and assistance.

Beyond her role at OHF, Kerry has long supported the military community as a Master Resilience Trainer, Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training (ASIST) facilitator, and Transition Assistance Program (TAP) employment facilitator. She also serves on the board of directors for the Military Special Operations Family Collaborative and sits on the TEACH Family Advisory Panel for the THRIVE program at UNC-Chapel Hill.

Her advocacy has earned recognition at the highest levels, including the President’s Lifetime Achievement Award, the Secretary of the Army’s Superior Public Service Medal, and three Military Spouse of the Year honors. Kerry is also a respected voice for military families as a columnist for Military Times, where her "The Home Front" column highlights the challenges and triumphs of military life.

Through her leadership, advocacy, and deep commitment to service, Kerry continues to drive meaningful change for the military and veteran communities OHF supports.

name: Ms. Maria Cherjovsky
title: Chief Executive Officer
bio:
Maria Cherjovsky has dedicated over 25 years to workforce development, nonprofit management, social services, and higher education, addressing employer needs while supporting underserved groups. She has held executive roles at the University of Central Florida and local nonprofits, including Vice President of Mission Services and Workforce Innovation for Goodwill Industries of Central Florida, Vice President of Operations for the Coalition for the Homeless, President of the Florida Diversity Council, President of the Central Florida Disability Chamber of Commerce (now the Florida Abilities and Inclusion Network), and Executive Director of AMCSI, a national disability inclusion organization. Additionally, Maria spent 10 years as a college professor and over 15 years as a career coach, instructional designer, project manager, marketing expert, and consultant, both domestically and internationally, helping transform organizations and develop high-performing teams.

Maria’s commitment extends beyond her professional roles, volunteering with community organizations, nonprofits, and workforce agencies for nearly two decades. She has served on the planning committee for the Interservice/Industry Training, Simulation, and Education Conference (I/ITSEC), the world’s largest modeling, simulation, and training event. Her contributions have been recognized by the United States Congress, National Diversity Council, National Defense Industrial Association, National Training & Simulation Association, Australian Royal Navy, Society for Human Resource Management, Gabor Organization, and the Adult and Continuing Higher Education Association (ACHE). In 2020, she received the inaugural "Diversity in Business Lifetime Achievement Award" from the Orlando Business Journal.

Maria holds a Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration and a Master’s degree in Instructional Systems Design. She has also completed coursework toward a doctoral degree and earned several Master’s certificates in Project Management, Human Resource Management, and Career Counseling. She is a National Diversity Council Certified Diversity Professional (NDCCDP) and a frequent speaker at regional and national conferences. Maria lives in Central Florida with her husband and children.

name: Command Sergeant Major (R.) Matt Kitchin
title: Former Commandant
company: Joint Special Operations University Enlisted Academy
bio:
CSM Matt Kitchin, a native of Vermont, enlisted in the United States Navy in January 1993. He attended basic training at Recruit Training Command and Aviation controller ‘A’ school in Great Lakes, Illinois, and was assigned to the USS SAIPAN LHA-2 based out of Norfolk Naval Base, Virginia. He enlisted in the United States Army in September 1998 as an M1 A-1 Abrams Tank Mechanic, attending Basic Training at Ft. Leonardwood, Missouri and Advanced Individual Training at Ft. Knox, Kentucky.  As an Abrams mechanic, he served at Fort Riley, Kansas and Fort Stewart, Georgia.  

CSM Kitchin attended Special Forces Assessment and Selection in 2001, graduating the Special Forces Qualification Course as an 18C (Special Forces Engineer) in 2003. Assigned to 10th Special Forces Group (Airborne), CSM Kitchin held positions as an Operational Detachment Alpha (ODA) Engineer, ODA Operations Sergeant, First Sergeant, Company Sergeant Major, BN Operations Sergeant Major and served as the 1ST BN 10TH SFG(A) Command Sergeant Major. He has also served at the NATO Special Operations Headquarters (NSHQ) on SHAPE, Mons, Belgium, as the NSHQ First Sergeant, and in Stuttgart Germany as the Special Operations Command Europe J3 Senior Enlisted Advisor. From 2008 to 2011, CSM Kitchin served at the Military Freefall School in Yuma, Arizona, as a basic course instructor and assisted in establishing the Advanced Tactical Infiltration Course (ATIC) in 2009.

CSM Kitchin has completed numerous combat deployments in support of Operation IRAQI FREEDOM, Operation ENDURING FREEDOM, and Operation ATLANTIC RESOLVE.
His awards and decorations include the Defense Meritorious Service Medal, Purple Hearts, Bronze Star, Army Commendation Medal and various unit and campaign awards. He has earned the Combat Infantry Badge, the Special Forces Tab, Master Parachutist Badge and Military Freefall Parachutist Jumpmaster Badge with combat star.
CSM Kitchin is a graduate of the Joint Special Operations Forces Senior Enlisted Academy at the Joint Special Operations University, MacDill AFB, Florida

name: Dr. Sarah Anderson, PsyD, CMPC
title: Director of Ascent Transition & Professional Development Program
company: U.S. Air Force Special Operations Command
bio:
Sarah is the director of the Ascent Transition & Professional Development Program within an AFSOC-GSU unit at Pope Army Airfield. Her background is in the sport and performance psychology and clinical counseling fields.  She has experience in those roles working for the Army and within collegiate and youth sports. She has her degree in sport psychology and master’s degree in clinical counseling and is a Certified Mental Performance Coach through the Association of Applied Sport Psychology. Her most important roles and achievements are that she is a mother to four children and a spouse to recently retired US Army Solider, Charlie.

Sarah was raised in a ‘dugout’ in Mobile AL, daughter to a collegiate baseball coach and elementary school teacher. She is the second of four children, and still very close (and competitive) with her siblings. Her journey working with the military began in 2013 in Fort Jackson, SC doing performance psychology training with Basic Combat Training trainees. Throughout multiple PCS’s and family-life changes, her passion to work for the military and provide meaningful skills-training & professional development to this population never wavered. In 2022 Sarah was assessed and selected to work for an elite Air Force Special Operations unit to run their new Transition and Professional Development program: Ascent.

Ascent assists its unit members and others within the SOF community to navigate their unique transition out of the military and into civilian life, helping them to find purpose and passion in their next chapter(s). Through personal one-on-one meetings, transition workshops, & networking events Ascent has provided personalized assistance to many SOF members as they begin their next meaningful journey. Sarah enjoys both the work with the service members, as well as the transition assistance community at large that she gets to interact and work with on a regular basis (Donovan & Bank, THF, Commit, Hiring our Heroes, SOTF, META, and so many more). In the last three years, Ascent has assisted over 300 special operators and support members as they transition from military into civilian life. Ascent also plays a role in developing and implementing the personal and professional development courses for the AFSOC unit it falls under. From developing courses for future Troop Chiefs and Team Leaders, to implementing soft skills development workshops, the Ascent program prepares its unit members to be the best while in uniform and after.

name: Mr. Tony Mayne
title: Executive Director
bio:
Tony Mayne is the Executive Director of GallantFew and a Transition Counselor for Three Rangers Foundation, serving the 75th Ranger Regiment. Previously, Tony served enlisted and as an officer in the Army for 20 years, with 12 years in the U.S. Special Operations Command, including nine years in the Ranger Regiment.

During his 14th year in service, Tony went through the Physical Evaluation Board process and, thanks to his leadership, was able to continue to serve, switching to the Public Affairs functional area. As the Regimental PAO, he spearheaded the creation of the Regiment’s operating concept for transition—Ranger for Life. While assigned to USSOCOM, his portfolio included the Warrior Care Program (Care Coalition) and the Preservation of the Force and Family (POTFF) programs.

Tony graduated from The Ohio State University with a B.A. in Political Science, completed the Ranger Indoctrination Program, and served in the 3rd Ranger Battalion. He was commissioned as an Infantry officer upon graduating from Clemson University with a Master’s in Human Resource Development. Tony served in the 1st Armor Division and 82nd Airborne Division before returning to the Ranger Regiment.

Tony’s purpose is to provide transitioning service members with timely access to the right resources delivered through counseling. He is a firm believer in the network approach when assisting service members with their reintegration into the civilian world.

name: Mr. Akash Jain
title: CTO & President of USG
bio:
Akash Jain currently serves as CTO and President of Palantir USG. His current areas of focus include driving Palantir’s 0→1 R&D portfolio including enabling AI/ML Ops across the USG business with Palantir’s Gotham and Foundry platforms. He spends most of his time iterating with mission partners, Palantir’s engineering teams and leaders across the civilian, defense and intelligence practice areas.

Mr. Jain joined Palantir in 2005 as a software engineer to design and build Palantir’s Gotham platform. From there, he led the deployment and iteration of Palantir’s platform across the defense and intelligence communities in the United States and alongside critical international partners. His areas of expertise include performance, scalability, security, cloud architecture, hybrid deployment models and edge solutions.

Mr. Jain graduated from Stanford University in 2003 with a degree in Computer Science. He now lives in Oakland, California where he enjoys spending time with his family.

name: Mr. Pete Greany
title: Program Executive Officer, PEO Services, SOF AT&L
bio:
Mr. Pete Greany is the Program Executive Officer (PEO) for Services (SV) Acquisition at USSOCOM’s Center for Special Operations Forces Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics (SOF AT&L), MacDill Air Force Base, Florida. He oversees USSOCOM’s service acquisitions, supporting Headquarters, Component Commands, and Theater Special Operations Commands with an annual total spend of $3.2 billion.

Previously, Mr. Greany served as Deputy PEO for SV since December 2021, providing executive oversight of service acquisitions. Before that, he was the Senior Program Manager for the Science and Technology (S&T) Directorate from 2018 to 2021, managing research, technology projects, SBIRs, and investment coordination between Components and Headquarters. From 2013 to 2018, he was Deputy Director for Silent Knight Radar for PEO Rotary Wing and Deputy Program Manager for Hostile Forces Tagging, Tracking, and Locating for PEO Special Reconnaissance, directing acquisition and fielding of SOF weapon and ISR systems. From 2008 to 2012, he managed USSOCOM Survivability and Individual Equipment for PEO SOF Warrior. After retiring from the Army in 2013, he transitioned to Federal Service.

Before USSOCOM, Mr. Greany held leadership roles in Army Staff, including Acquisition Branch assignment officer, Assistant Program Manager at the National Reconnaissance Office, and Combat Developer for Army Intelligence and Security Command. Commissioned as an Infantry Officer in 1992, he commanded two companies and served in leadership roles in the U.S., Europe, Southwest Asia, South America, and North Africa with the U.S. Army Infantry and Acquisition Corps.

A DAWIA Level III certified Program Manager and Acquisition Corps member, Mr. Greany holds a Bachelor’s in International Relations from the U.S. Military Academy and an MBA from Webster University. He is married to Shannon, with whom he shares four children: Megan, Monyka, Madison, and Justin.

name: Mr. Chris Wilson
title: Science and Technology Directorate, Capability Area Lead for Warfighter Performance
bio: Mr Chris Wilson is currently the USSOCOM SOFAT&L – Science and Technology Directorate, Capability Area Lead for Warfighter Performance.  Chris retired after 21+ years as a Medical Plans \ Acquisition Officer in the US Army in 2016.  Has been at USSOCOM since 2013 and has managed SOCOM Biomedical & Human Performance Research Portfolio since 2021. While serving in the Army, Chris had 2 combat deployments to Afghanistan and a NATO deployment to Bosnia-Herzegovina

name: Mr. Garth Arevalo
title: Chief Executive Officer
bio: Garth Arevalo is CEO of Lukos. Lukos is a rapidly growing federal contractor. Lukos has prime contracts supporting the military services, joint combatant commands, Department of Homeland Security, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention with a focus on training, analytics, healthcare, and professional support. Prior to co-founding Lukos, he served in the Air Force and at Special Operations Command as a Contracting Officer. He has worked supporting special operations forces throughout the world for most of his career. He has a BS-Business Administration from Georgetown University and an MS in Entrepreneurship from the University of South Florida.

name: First Sergeant (Ret.) Valerie Lavin
title: CEO, Luminary
bio:
Valerie Ellis Lavin is a retired Army First Sergeant and the CEO of Luminary Global, along with her husband, Jeremy Lavin, the company's COO. Luminary helps prevent death by providing emergency product solutions to those who are the lifeline between preventable death and hospital care.

Philanthropically, Valerie is known for her devotion to helping veterans start their businesses. Valerie's experience in startup education, program development, and event execution led to a partnership with other military veterans and spouses to create Action Zone, Inc. Recently, Valerie was named Bunker Labs Director of Ecosystem Development.

name: Mr. Kit Werremeyer
title: Emeritus Chairman
bio: Expertise in private construction, engineering, contracts and international business. 32 years US and international experience with engineering and construction business for major Engineering, Construction and Procurement (EPC) contractors in the oil, gas, refining, LNG, power, water, chemical and petrochemical sectors. Former executive with CBI, an international EPC contractor. 22 years as Owner/President of Southernstar Consultants LLC providing professional services for construction contracts training, claims and dispute resolution, and international trade with Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines, China and Japan. Provide training courses in construction contracts. Assistance with negotiating fair and balanced terms and conditions in construction contracts. Author of the book: "Understanding and Negotiating Construction Contracts" Second edition pubished in September, 2003. Available at Amazon.com and many other bookseller sites. US Army Vietnam war veteran.

name: Ms. Rosalinda Vasquez Maury
title: Director of Applied Research and Analytics
company: Syracuse University’s D’Aniello Institute for Veterans and Military Families (IVMF)
bio: Rosalinda Vasquez Maury serves as the Director of Applied Research and Analytics at the D’Aniello Institute of Veterans and Military Families (IVMF) at Syracuse University. She works on a diverse research portfolio that reflects the range of social, economic, and wellness challenges that may affect transitioning service members, veterans, or their families. She has worked on numerous research efforts including workforce readiness as it relates to transitioning service members and veterans in the civilian labor force, career preferences, financial readiness, job matching and employer perspectives on retention and workplace performance, factors impacting veteran and military families business owners, and service members experiences in higher education. She has extensive experience in survey development and worldwide data collection, and has been responsible for developing, implementing and managing surveys for data collection on the large and small scale, for organizations and government sectors. Her work has been featured in numerous publication and has presented at various professional conferences. Maury holds a master’s of science and bachelor’s degrees in psychology from the University of Texas at San Antonio.

name: Mr. Luis Martinez
title: Senior Pentagon Reporter
bio: He has covered the U.S. military and national security issues for ABC News from the Pentagon since 2006. Prior to beginning his role at the Pentagon, Martinez covered the State Department and the U.S. Senate for ABC News. He began his career at ABC in 1989 as a desk assistant and later worked as an assignment editor and a producer in the D.C. bureau, covering a variety of national issues in Washington. Martinez is a graduate of Columbia University.

name: The Honorable Pedro Arnulfo Sánchez Suárez
title: Minister of Defense

name: General Raimundas Vaikšnoras
title: Chief of Defense
bio:
General Raimundas Vaikšnoras was born on 12 July 1970 in Druskininkai. He started his military career on 28 February 1991 when he was assigned as an intelligence specialist to the Training Unit of the National Defence Department of Lithuania. He took the serviceman's oath on 11 March 1991.

During his military service the General followed the path of a soldier, a sergeant and an officer. He started from the position of rifleman, then as NCO he was a section and platoon commander, later began his career as an officer. General Raimundas Vaikšnoras graduated from Platoon and Company Commander Courses in Denmark, Staff Officer Courses in Germany, Lithuania and Sweden, Joint Command and General Staff Officer Course in the Baltic Defence College, Estonia, as well as the Strategic Defence Studies at the United States Army War College. During his military service in the Lithuanian Armed Forces R. Vaikšnoras served as the Platoon and Company Commander of the Motorized Infantry troops, he was the Commander of two battalions in Rukla and Vilnius, and the Commander of the Mechanized Infantry Brigade “Iron Wolf”. In his military service, he also took the positions of staff officer and chief officer of combat training, defence planning and operations control. Once he was deployed to serve in a mission headquarters in Afghanistan. 

During his senior staff officer's career, the General was responsible for capability development and operations in the Land Force Headquarters, Joint Staff and Defence Staff of the Lithuanian Armed Forces. General R. Vaikšnoras' decorations include the Commemorative Badge to Mark Russian Troops Withdrawal from Lithuania, Medal of the Founding Volunteers of the Lithuanian Army, Honor Badge “Iron Wolf”, National Defence System of the Republic of Lithuania Medal for Deployment on International Missions, Lithuanian Armed Forces and Land Forces Medals for Distinguished Service, Lithuanian Armed Forces Medal of Merit (with Bronze Pillars) and other awards. Gen R. Vaikšnoras is a member of the Union of Founding Volunteers of the Lithuanian Armed Forces.

name: General Javier Iturriaga del Campo
title: Commander in Chief of the Army
bio:
General Javier Iturriaga del Campo entered the Chilean Army Military Academy in 1980 and graduated as a Second Lieutenant from the Infantry Branch on January 1st, 1984.

He holds the primary specialty of Staff Officer and secondary specialties of Commando and Paratrooper.

Latest Promotions and Assignments


December 2004: Promoted to Lieutenant Colonel.
December 2009: Promoted to Colonel.
January 2012: Appointed Commander of the Reinforced Regiment No. 4 "Rancagua".
January 2013: Appointed Commander of the 2nd Armored Brigade "Cazadores".
January 2014: Appointed Military Attaché in Brazil.
December 2014: Promoted to Brigadier General and appointed Commander of the Special Operations Brigade “Lautaro”.
December 2016: Appointed Director of Army Operations.
December 2017: Appointed Deputy Chief of the Army General Staff.
November 2018: Promoted to Major General and appointed Commander of Education and Doctrine.
December 2020: Appointed Chief of the Joint Army Staff.
November 2021: Appointed Army Commander-in-Chief.
March 09, 2022: Took office as Commander-in-Chief of the Army.

Academic Background

Military Academy Professor in the subject of Tactics and Operations
Bachelor’s Degree in Military Science.
Master’s Degree in Military Science, specializing in Strategic Planning and Management, Chilean Army War College.

name: Senator Nicolae Ionel Ciucă
title: Former Minister of Defense
bio:
Nicolae-Ionel Ciucă was born on February 7, 1967, in Plenița, Dolj County, Romania. He graduated from Tudor Vladimirescu Military High School in 1985 and from the Nicolae Bălcescu Land Forces Academy in 1988. He later completed advanced studies at the National Defence University in Bucharest (1993–1995) and graduated from the U.S. War College in 2006.

His military career spans over three decades, progressing from platoon leader to brigade commander, and later to top leadership positions within the Romanian Armed Forces. He served in multiple international missions, including UNAVEM III in Angola (1996), ENDURING FREEDOM in Afghanistan (2002–2003), and ANTICA BABILONIA in Iraq (2004) as Battalion Commander.

In 2011, he was appointed Commander of the 2nd Infantry Division, followed by leadership of the Romanian Land Forces Staff in 2014. Later that year, he became Deputy Chief of Defence Staff and served as Chief of Defence (2015–2019), the highest military position in Romania. He was Minister of National Defence from November 2019 to December 2021.

Appointed Prime Minister in December 2021, he led the Romanian Government until June 2023. He then served as President of the Romanian Senate until December 2024.

Throughout his career, General (Ret.) Ciucă completed several prestigious courses, including the Peacekeeping Operations Instructor Course (Turkey), Joint and Multinational Operations Course, and Civil Military Cooperation training (USA). He also participated in numerous multinational exercises such as Blue Danube 2000, ISAF 2003, and Eurasian Star 2010.

His service has been recognized with high-level honors, including the National Order of Merit (Officer and Knight), the UN Medal for UNAVEM III, the French National Order of Merit (Commander), the U.S. Medal of Merit, and the Medal of Honor from the U.S. Special Operations Forces.

He speaks English fluently, is married, and has one son.

name: General Songwit Noonpakdee
title: Chief of Defense
bio:
General Songwit Noonpackdee is the 35th Chief of Defence Forces. A native of Bangkok, he is a graduate of Chulalongkorn University Demonstration Secondary School, the Armed Forces Academies Preparatory School, Thailand (AF Class 24) and the Virginia Military Institute, USA (VMI Class of 1988).

He has completed several courses, such as the Queen’s Tiger Soldiers Course, the Counter-Terrorism Course, and the Officers Royal Guard Course from King’s Bodyguard School (Class 11/60). He is also a graduate of 2 professional military education courses from the Command and General Staff College (Class 75) and Thailand’s National Defense College (Class 62) in 1997 and 2019 respectively. He received his Master Degree of Science in Civil Engineering from the Florida Institute of Technology and the United States Army Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, where he was inducted to the International Hall of Fame in 2024. He is a graduate of Airborne School, Pathfinder School, and Ranger School at Fort Benning. He also successfully completed the VIP Protection course from US Diplomatic Security Service. 

General Songwit was commissioned from VMI as an infantry officer. His first assignment was Platoon Leader of the 3rd LRRP Company, 3rd Infantry Division in Nakhon Ratchasima Province, followed by Operations Officer for the 1st LRRP Company, 1st Division, King’s Guard. He, then, served as Heavy Mortar Company Commander for the 21st Infantry Regiment, Queen’s Guard. Following that, he was an instructor at the Command and General Staff College in 1996. 

General Songwit’s command assignments were mainly in the 11th Infantry Regiment, King’s Guard, 1st Division, King’s Guard in Bangkok as Commander of 3rd Infantry Battalion, Commander of 2nd Infantry Battalion. In 2011, he was the Commander of 11th Infantry Regiment, King’s Guard. His senior command assignments were at the 1st Division, King’s Guard as Chief of Staff and Commanding General of the 1st Division, King’s Guard in 2018. He also served as the Commanding General of 11th Infantry Division in 2017, which marked the beginning of an era of the Stryker Division in the Royal Thai Army. 

His key staff assignments were Deputy Commanding General of the 1st Army Area in 2019, Deputy Chief of Staff (Operations) of the Royal Thai Army, then Royal Thai Army was Chief of the Staff Officers to the Commander-in-Chief. 

In October 2023, General Songwit assumed command as the 35th Chief of Defence Forces.

name: Colonel T. Justin Bronder
title: Program Executive Officer, PEO Fixed Wing Programs
bio:
Col Bronder is currently serving as the Program Executive Officer (PEO) for Fixed Wing Programs, HQ Special Operations Command (USSOCOM). He is responsible for developing, producing, testing, modifying, fielding and supporting Special Operations Forces (SOF)-unique fixed wing aircraft and sub-systems. This diverse, $2 billion annual portfolio includes over 100 programs and projects, furnishing SOF-unique aviation capabilities such as the AC-130 and MC-130 variants, OA-1K, MQ-1C, MQ-9, CV-22, U-28, MC-12, C-145, C-146 and an array of remotely piloted vehicles and precision guided munitions.

A 2003 Air Force Academy distinguished graduate, Justin earned the Holaday Scholarship and completed a Doctorate in Astrophysics at Oxford University before serving at the Air Force Research Laboratory. He then qualified as a flight test engineer, graduating the USAF Test Pilot School with distinction in 2011, and served at the 413th Flight Test Squadron, Hurlburt Field, FL, leading test programs on the CV-22 and several C-130 variants. After selection as an Olmsted Scholar in 2013, Lt Col Bronder spent two years in Poland, where he earned a Doctorate in Military History at Adam Mickiewicz University. Returning to the U.S., he worked as a deputy program manager for the UH-1N replacement program before being selected as a Materiel Leader for the Nuclear Treaty Monitoring Systems Division at the Air Force Technical Applications Center, FL. He is also a distinguished graduate and Traeger Award winner from National War College and deployed in 2008 in support of U.S. Special Operations Command. He most recently served as a Military Assistant to the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Sustainment (A&S) and as a Deputy Division Chief for Strategic Deterrence and Capabilities in the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition and Sustainment, Strategic, Space and Intelligence Portfolio Management.

name: Mr. Howard Strahan
title: Deputy Director, SOF AT&L Science and Technology Directorate
bio:
Mr. Howard Strahan Jr. is the Deputy Director, SOF AT&L Science and Technology Directorate for the United States Special Operations Command (USSOCOM), MacDill Air Force Base, Florida. He is responsible for supporting the Director in the execution of Command Research and Development activities and has over 30 years of Federal Service.

Mr. Strahan’s career began in 1989 designing Signal Intelligence (SIGINT), Communication Jamming Trainers, and Communication Security (COMSEC) platforms for the United States Air Force Air Intelligence Agency. He then worked in Europe conducting open-source science and technology reporting for the United States Army Materiel Command, Science and Technology Center – Europe. He was the Technical Director of the Consolidated SIGINT Support Activity (CSSA) and served as the Program Manager for the Airborne and Ground Support Depot for the Air Force Technical Applications Center (AFTAC).

Mr. Strahan was later promoted to Chief Engineer for the 77 Aeronautical Systems Group, 77 Aeronautical Systems Wing, providing technical oversight and having Operational Suitability, Safety, and Effectiveness (OSS&E) responsibility for the development and sustainment of all USAF Aircrew Protection Equipment, Aeromedical Evacuation Equipment, and Chemical/Biological Defense Equipment.

In 2008, Mr. Strahan transitioned to MacDill AFB, Florida, with USSOCOM SOAL–T (now known as SOF AT&L-ST), where he executed BA2 and BA3 funds in support of biomedical, optics, and weapons research. This led to his role as Strategic Engagement Lead for SOF AT&L-ST, where he provided outreach to outside agencies and discovery support for Applied Research and Advanced Technology Development funding aimed at addressing USSOCOM capability gaps. He has also provided technical leadership to the programs executing in these critical areas.

Mr. Strahan holds a Master’s of National Security and Strategic Studies from the United States Naval War College, a Master’s of Business Administration in Aerospace Defense from the University of Tennessee, and a Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering from Texas A&M University. He is Level III acquisition certified in Systems Planning, Research, Development, and Engineering and is a current member of the Air Force Acquisition Corps.

name: Sergeant Major (Ret.) Matt Parrish
title: Executive Director, Task Force Dagger Foundation
bio:
Matt is a retired Green Beret who spent his entire 20-year career within Special Operations, including 13 years on Army Special Forces operational teams. He completed multiple combat tours to Iraq and Afghanistan as well as training and operational tours to most of the countries in Central and South America. He’s the recipient of numerous leadership awards, service medals, and specialized certifications in some of the world’s toughest disciplines. He rose to the highest enlisted rank in the U.S. Army and his final position was the Senior Enlisted Leader for the USSOCOM Preservation of the Force and Family program – overseeing human performance and wellness for over 70k special ops individuals across the globe.

Matt has also narrated and performed across the country at college and professional sporting events with the SOCOM Para-Commando parachute demonstration team and he created and hosted SOCOM’s first official podcast, SOFcast. He’s recently created a new podcast called Prep For Impact that highlights authentic conversations with high achievers across special ops, sports, business, non-profit and other impactful careers. Matt also uses his popular military humor Instagram page, Another_SF_meme_page to raise money and awareness for veteran and military charities and causes. He’s a frequent guest on podcasts, radio shows, and speaking engagements.

Matt has been married for over 16 years, has three children, is hopelessly addicted to golf, and believes fervently in Philippians 4:13.

name: Sergeant Major Thomas P. Payne
title: Medal of Honor Recipient
bio:
Sergeant First Class Thomas P. Payne distinguished himself by extraordinary gallantry and heroism above and beyond the call of duty during a daring nighttime hostage rescue on October 22, 2015, in Kirkuk Province, Iraq, in support of Operation INHERENT RESOLVE. Leading a combined assault team, Sergeant Payne swiftly cleared one building, freeing 38 hostages. Upon hearing calls for assistance at the second building under heavy enemy fire, he voluntarily crossed the open compound under fire to aid the assault.

Climbing onto the burning roof, Sergeant Payne engaged enemy fighters with grenades and small arms fire, then moved to ground level, firing through a breach to suppress resistance. With time running out and the building engulfed in flames, he courageously entered through heavy gunfire, locating the armored door imprisoning the hostages. After exiting to retrieve bolt cutters, he reentered under enemy fire to cut the locks. His actions inspired other coalition members to join the effort.

Despite orders to evacuate the collapsing building, Sergeant Payne reentered multiple times to ensure no one was left behind, facilitating the release and evacuation of 37 additional hostages. Throughout the operation, he repeatedly exposed himself to intense enemy fire, smoke, and structural collapse. His heroism directly contributed to the liberation of 75 hostages and the elimination of 20 enemy combatants.

Sergeant First Class Payne’s selfless actions, bravery under fire, and unwavering commitment to mission success uphold the highest traditions of military service and reflect immense credit upon himself, the United States Special Operations Command, and the United States Army.

name: Master Sergeant Earl D. Plumlee
title: Medal of Honor Recipient
bio:
Staff Sergeant Earl D. Plumlee distinguished himself by extraordinary gallantry above and beyond the call of duty on August 28, 2013, while serving as a weapons sergeant with C Company, 4th Battalion, 1st Special Forces Group (Airborne) in support of Operation Enduring Freedom. When insurgents detonated an explosion that created a 60-foot breach in Forward Operating Base Ghazni's perimeter, ten enemy fighters wearing Afghan National Army uniforms and suicide vests poured through.

Sergeant Plumlee and five others rushed toward the breach in two vehicles. Under enemy fire, Plumlee shielded his driver with his body before exiting and engaging an insurgent 15 meters away with his pistol. Without cover and at great personal risk, he advanced on and engaged multiple insurgents, killing two—one with a grenade and another by detonating his suicide vest with precision sniper fire.

Despite intense fire, Sergeant Plumlee repeatedly advanced against enemy forces, engaging insurgents at close range, even after a suicide vest exploded within seven meters, throwing him against a wall. Ignoring his injuries, he reengaged the enemy alongside another soldier. When enemy fire forced a brief withdrawal, Sergeant Plumlee joined a group of American and Polish soldiers to launch another counterattack.

During the renewed assault, Plumlee engaged multiple insurgents, including one who detonated his vest, fatally wounding a U.S. soldier. Plumlee ran to the wounded soldier, carried him to safety, rendered first aid, and remained on security to clear the area of further threats.

Staff Sergeant Plumlee’s remarkable bravery, disregard for his own safety, and decisive actions were instrumental in repelling the attack and saving lives. His actions reflect great credit upon himself, the Special Forces Regiment, and the United States Army.

name: Master Sergeant Matthew O. Williams
title: Medal of Honor Recipient
bio:
Sergeant Matthew O. Williams distinguished himself by acts of gallantry and intrepidity above and beyond the call of duty on April 6, 2008, while serving as a Weapons Sergeant with Special Forces Operational Detachment Alpha 3336, Special Operations Task Force-33, in Afghanistan. Inserted by helicopter, Sergeant Williams’ assault element came under intense enemy machine gun, sniper, and rocket-propelled grenade fire while ascending a mountain toward its objective. The lead element, including the ground commander, sustained casualties and was pinned down on the mountainside.

Upon learning of the situation, Sergeant Williams braved heavy fire to lead a counterattack across a valley filled with ice-covered boulders and a waist-deep, freezing river. Reaching the pinned-down element, he organized Afghan commandos to deliver suppressive fire, preventing enemy overrunning of the position. When the Team Sergeant was wounded, Williams exposed himself to enemy fire to render aid and move him down the steep terrain to a casualty collection point.

Despite danger, Sergeant Williams climbed back up the mountain to help defend the assault element, reestablished critical satellite communications under fire, and assisted in moving additional wounded soldiers to safety. As enemy forces threatened the casualty collection point, Williams led a counterattack that held off the insurgents for hours.

When evacuation helicopters arrived, Sergeant Williams repeatedly exposed himself to enemy fire to carry and load the wounded onto the aircraft, all while directing fire to suppress enemy positions. His courageous actions enabled the successful evacuation of wounded and fallen comrades without further loss of life. Sergeant Williams’ extraordinary bravery, selflessness, and leadership under fire were pivotal in saving the lives of four critically wounded soldiers and preventing the assault element from being overrun.

His actions reflect great credit upon himself, the Combined Joint Special Operations Task Force-Afghanistan, Special Operations Command Central, and the United States Army.

name: Colonel Rhea Pritchett
title: Program Executive Officer, PEO SOF Digital Applications (SDA), SOF AT&L

name: Colonel Christopher Paone
title: J4 Logistics Directorate
bio:
Colonel Christopher L. Paone serves as the Director of Logistics (J4) at U.S. Special Operations Command (USSOCOM), overseeing operational logistics support for Special Operations Forces (SOF) worldwide. His responsibilities include materiel management, cataloging, provisioning, and fielding Special Operations-peculiar equipment.

Prior to this role, Colonel Paone commanded the 10th Support Group at Torii Station, Okinawa. He previously led the Group Support Battalion, 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne) at Fort Bragg (2015–2017), and later served at the Combined Arms Support Command (Fort Lee, Virginia) and Army Sustainment Command (Rock Island Arsenal).

A native of Ramsey, New Jersey, Colonel Paone commissioned into the Quartermaster Corps through the Providence College ROTC program. Early assignments included Platoon Leader, Company Executive Officer, and Petroleum Operations Officer with the 260th Quartermaster Battalion at Hunter Army Airfield, Georgia, and service in Bosnia/Herzegovina with the 148th Logistics Task Force.

From 2003–2014, he held key logistics roles at Fort Bragg, including Group Assistant S4 and Service Detachment Commander with the 7th Special Forces Group (Airborne); Services Officer in the 82nd Airborne Division; and Group S4 for 7th SFG (A). He also served as Aide-de-Camp at the U.S. Army War College, and as Logistics Coordinator for the Armed Forces Inauguration Committee during a presidential inauguration.

Colonel Paone later served as an Interagency Fellow at FEMA in Washington, D.C., and as National Programs and Employment Director for the Soldier For Life Program on the Army Staff. He deployed multiple times to Afghanistan in support of the Combined Joint Special Operations Task Force and Combined Joint Task Force-82.

Colonel Paone holds a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration from Providence College, and master’s degrees in Business Administration (University of Maryland University College), Logistics Management (Florida Institute of Technology), and Strategic Studies (U.S. Army War College).

He is married and has two children.

name: Colonel Stephen Murphy
title: Command Engineer
bio:
Col. Stephen F. Murphy has served as the USSOCOM Command Engineer since October 2022, advising the Commander on construction, facilities, and engineering matters. He represents USSOCOM to the Department of Defense, Services, Combatant Commands, Interagency, and Congress, and oversees operational engineering support for SOF components and a $4 billion military construction program at MacDill AFB.

With over 26 years of experience across the USSOCOM enterprise, Col. Murphy has held key engineering roles at JSOC, USASOAC, and 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne), among others. He deployed three times to Afghanistan and once to Iraq, serving notably as the J-7 Engineer for CJSOTF-A.

He has commanded at all levels, including as District Commander of the USACE New Orleans District (2019–2022) and the USACE Nashville District (2015–2017). His earlier assignments include the 20th Engineer Battalion, 2nd Infantry Division in Korea, the 307th Engineer Battalion, and the 2/2 Stryker Brigade Combat Team at Joint Base Lewis-McChord. His humanitarian missions include deployments to Bosnia-Herzegovina, Hurricane Katrina recovery efforts, and forest firefighting in Montana.

Col. Murphy holds a Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering from the Illinois Institute of Technology, a Master of Science in Civil Engineering from Missouri University of Science and Technology, and a Master of Arts in Strategy from the U.S. Army War College.

He is a graduate of the U.S. Army War College, U.S. Marine Corps Command and Staff College, and multiple Army Engineer courses. His military qualifications include the Ranger Tab, Sapper Tab, Master Parachutist Badge, and Combat Action Badge.

His awards include the Legion of Merit, Bronze Star Medal (with two oak leaf clusters), Defense Meritorious Service Medal (with one oak leaf cluster), Army Meritorious Service Medal (five oak leaf clusters), and NATO medals for Bosnia and Afghanistan, among others. He is also a recipient of the Army Engineer Association’s Silver and Bronze de Fleury Medals.

Col. Murphy is married to Nicole, and together they have two teenage children, Will and Claire.

name: Colonel Ramsey Oliver
title: Program Executive Officer SOF Warrior Systems
bio:
Colonel R. Ramsey Oliver is a native of Albany, Georgia, and a 2002 Distinguished Military Graduate of North Georgia College & State University in Dahlonega, where he earned a Bachelor of Business Administration in Finance.  Upon graduation, he commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the Finance Corps with a branch detail assignment to the Infantry.  In July 2010, he transitioned to the U.S. Army Acquisition Corps.  
COL Oliver is currently the Program Executive Officer for Special Operations Forces Warrior Systems (PEO-SW) at USSOCOM where he is responsible for management, direction, and guidance for the planning, development, acquisition, testing, & product improvement of technologies and equipment that place critical capabilities in the hands of special operators.  He oversees an annual $1.6B portfolio with 10 program management offices dispersed across the United States.  Previous USSOCOM assignments include the Director of Test & Evaluation & the Program Manager for USSOCOM’s Counter Proliferation Office in PEO-SW.  
His other previous acquisition assignments include Contract Management Officer, 708th Contingency Contracting Team; Deputy Chief, Regional Contracting Center Jalalabad, Afghanistan; Chief of Current Operations, U.S. Central Command Joint Theater Contracting Support Command, Camp As Sayliyah, Qatar; Career Manager for Acquisition Management Branch, Human Resources Command, Fort Knox, Kentucky; Assistant Product Manager in Soldier Maneuver Sensors, Soldier Sensors & Lasers, Program Executive Office Soldier, Fort Belvoir, Virginia; Executive Officer to the Principal Military Deputy to the Assistant Secretary of the Army (Acquisition, Logistics & Technology), Pentagon, Washington, DC.   
COL Oliver has completed an Operation Enduring Freedom tour & two Operation Iraqi Freedom tours. He earned a Master’s in Strategic Studies from Air University at Maxwell Air Force Base, AL & a Master of Business Administration from Webster University in Saint Louis, Missouri.  His military education includes the Infantry Officer Basic Course, Mechanized Leaders Course, Modern Army Combatives Instructor Course, Antiterrorism/Force Protection Level II Training Course, Finance Officer Advanced Course, Planning Programming Budgeting and Execution Systems Course, Resource Management Tactical Course, Comptrollers Accreditation & Fiscal Law Course, Army Acquisition Basic Course, Intermediate Program Manager & Contracting Courses, Command & General Staff Coll

name: Mr. Colby Jenkins
title: Assistant Secretary of Defense for Special Operations Low Intensity Conflict (Acting)
bio:
Mr. Colby Jenkins is an Army Special Forces combat veteran and currently is performing the duties of Assistant Secretary of Defense for Special Operations and Low Intensity Conflict. Colby was previous appointed as the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Irregular Warfare and Counterterrorism in the Office of the Secretary of Defense.

Upon graduating from West Point, Colby became an airborne Ranger-qualified infantry officer before trying out for and being selected to become a Special Forces officer. As a Green Beret Detachment Commander, Colby led his Special Forces A-team on multiple global deployments, including combat in Afghanistan and later various training, counter-drug, and hostage rescue operations throughout South America, including the jungles of Colombia.

Colby’s experience in combat and leading his team opened new opportunities to serve beyond the fields of battle. The four-star commanding general of the United States Special Operations Command (USSOCOM) hand-selected Colby to initiate a new congressional fellowship program that included graduate school in Washington, D.C., and working in a U.S. Senator’s office. Colby would be the first special operations officer to do so for USSOCOM, creating a path for many others to follow. After Colby’s work in the U.S. Senate and completing graduate school, Colby continued his work on Capitol Hill as a Green Beret liaison to Congress. This experience took him from the halls of Congress around the world with members of Congress and staff. Colby later worked in the Pentagon as a counterterrorism policy advisor to the Secretary of Defense, coordinating critical efforts between the White House, Pentagon, Capitol Hill, and other interagency partners to advance American interests.

After completing his active-duty military service Colby transitioned to the Army National Guard and now the Army Reserves where he continued his military service for more than two decades. During his civilian career, Colby remained active in the legislative arena working for several years in the Pentagon as the senior civilian legislative strategic advisor to the Vice-Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation’s #2 military leader.

name: Dr. Lyla Kohistany
title: CEO, Honor the Promise;
bio:
Lyla is an Afghan refugee, U.S. Navy veteran (Surface Warfare & Intelligence), entrepreneur, organizational enhancer, and innovation igniter. With three Afghanistan deployments alongside U.S./NATO Special Operations Forces (SOF) and tours in the Pentagon, she has enjoyed a distinguished career contributing to counterterrorism, counterinsurgency, and all-source intelligence operations.

Lyla is also a lauded corporate educator, having designed and facilitated hundreds of interactive/experiential programs on cultural intelligence, organizational performance, innovation, and inspirational leadership. She is a sought-after speaker and moderator, has been featured in various media, and contributed to numerous podcasts. She also co-founded two nationwide nonprofits, PROMOTE Leadership and Honor the Promise.

Lyla was a Scholar at the George W. Bush Presidential Center and a nonresident Senior Fellow at The Atlantic Council. She also served on the Board of Directors for The Honor Foundation. She is currently a Senior Fellow with The Soufan Center, an Ambassador for the Global War on Terrorism Memorial Foundation, a member of the Global SOF Foundation’s Advisory Council, and on the Board of Directors for the Corioli Institute.

Lyla earned a Doctor of Education (EdD) in Leadership and Innovation from Arizona State University. She is a Star Trek and Star Wars aficionada, international traveler, and devoted aunt to her niece and nephews.

name: Colonel Naoto Kuwahara
title: Commander
bio:
Colonel Kuwahara serves as the 8th Commanding Officer of the Special Operations Group, representing the Japanese Special Forces and bringing a distinct perspective on military operations. With an esteemed career encompassing various international and domestic assignments, Colonel Kuwahara has demonstrated exceptional leadership and operational expertise.

He will provide valuable insights into regional security challenges which Japan faces to Russia and PRC, the role of the Japanese military in addressing these issues within the maritime domain, and the operational dynamics of Special Operations Forces (SOF) in the Indo-Pacific region. Additionally, Colonel Kuwahara will outline his vision for establishing a SOF network in the Asia-Pacific, promoting cooperation and collaboration among allied nations.

name: Lieutenant Commander Roxana Alexandru
bio:
LTCDR Roxana Alexandru is a naval engineer with a 20 years’ experience as a military officer. She started her career being appointed as a navigation officer onboard Romanian minesweepers and afterwards on the type 22 frigates, participating in various NATO and allied exercises and missions, including the first and only NATO Article 5 activation which happened after 9/11 attacks, maritime operation Active Endeavour in the eastern Mediterranean Sea.

After graduating the Joint Command Master’s program at the Romanian National Defense University, in 2022, she was appointed in the Romanian Ministry of Defense and currently she serves as the Romanian liaison officer to US CENTCOM.

name: Commander Mike Ameche
title: Director of Leadership Development & Assessment
bio:
CDR Mike Ameche is the current NSW Director of Leadership Development & Assessment, and represents Naval Special Warfare Command and the United States. 

The Commander has 24 years of special operations experience spanning several maritime environments and threats including the Middle East, Indo-Pacific, and Homeland.  His operational tours include SEAL Team THREE, SEAL Team SEVEN, SEAL Team FIVE, and Special Reconnaissance Team ONE.  Staff and education tours include Special Operations Command NORTH and the Naval Postgraduate School.

name: Lieutenant Commander Luca Meca
title: Navy Special Operations Forces
bio:
LCDR Meca serves as head of the R&A office of the ITA NAVY SOF - Gruppo Operativo Incursori (GOI). 
He completed Italian SEAL training, earning the corresponding qualification and joining the GOI, the Italian Navy’s Special Forces unit. Established in 1952, GOI is the successor to Italy’s wartime assault craft units and frogman of the Second World War. 
Luca has operational experience in both national and multinational contexts, in Italy and overseas, working closely with other Italian Special Forces as well as allied and partner units. In  2012, he completed a one-year exchange programme in Virgina, USA, with NSWG2.
His background will provide valuable insights into the challenges that such regions is facing in terms of Special Ops and about the posture of the Italian Special Forces are having in relations to it.

name: Dr. Seth Jones
title: President, Defense and Security Department; Harold Brown Chair
bio:
Seth G. Jones is president of the Defense and Security Department and Harold Brown Chair at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS). He focuses on defense strategy, military operations, force posture, and irregular warfare. He leads a bipartisan team of over 50 resident staff and an extensive network of non-resident affiliates dedicated to providing independent strategic insights and policy solutions that shape national security. He also teaches at Johns Hopkins University’s School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS) and the Center for Homeland Defense and Security (CHDS) at the U.S. Naval Postgraduate School.

Prior to joining CSIS, Dr. Jones was the director of the International Security and Defense Policy Center at the RAND Corporation. He also served as representative for the commander, U.S. Special Operations Command, to the assistant secretary of defense for special operations. Before that, he was a plans officer and adviser to the commanding general, U.S. Special Operations Forces, in Afghanistan (Combined Forces Special Operations Component Command–Afghanistan). In 2014, Dr. Jones served on a congressionally mandated panel that reviewed the FBI’s implementation of counterterrorism recommendations contained in the 9/11 Commission Report. He is the author of Three Dangerous Men: Russia, China, Iran, and the Rise of Irregular Warfare (W.W. Norton, 2021), A Covert Action: Reagan, the CIA, and the Cold War Struggle in Poland (W.W. Norton, 2018), Waging Insurgent Warfare: Lessons from the Vietcong to the Islamic State (Oxford University Press, 2016), Hunting in the Shadows: The Pursuit of al Qa'ida since 9/11 (W.W. Norton, 2012), and In the Graveyard of Empires: America’s War in Afghanistan (W.W. Norton, 2009). Dr. Jones has published articles in a range of journals, such as Foreign Affairs, Foreign Policy, and International Security, as well as newspapers and magazines like the New York Times, Washington Post, and Wall Street Journal. Dr. Jones is a graduate of Bowdoin College and received his MA and PhD from the University of Chicago.

name: Ms. Katherine Boyle
title: General Partner
bio:
Katherine Boyle is a General Partner at Andreessen Horowitz and cofounder of the firm’s American Dynamism practice, which invests in companies supporting the national interest across aerospace, defense, manufacturing, energy, logistics, and critical infrastructure. She sits on the boards of Apex Space and Hadrian Automation and is a board observer for Saronic Technologies and Castelion.

She was previously a partner at General Catalyst, where she co-led the firm’s seed practice and invested in the inception rounds of defense technology companies including Anduril Industries and Vannevar Labs. Prior to General Catalyst, she was a general assignment reporter at The Washington Post. Katherine holds a BA in Government from Georgetown University, an MBA from Stanford and a Masters of Public Advocacy from the National University of Ireland, Galway.

Katherine believes that free speech is essential to promoting American Dynamism. She is a proud champion of new media companies and academic centers that promote free speech and free thought. She serves on the boards of The Free Press and the Mercatus Center at George Mason University.

name: Vice Admiral Frank D. Whitworth
title: Director
bio:
Vice Admiral Frank Whitworth is the eighth Director of the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency. He leads and directs NGA under the authorities of the Secretary of Defense and Director of National Intelligence. He became NGA’s director on June 3, 2022.

Whitworth is a 1989 graduate of Duke University Durham, North Carolina, with a Bachelor of Arts in Political Science. He holds a Master of Arts in National Security Studies from Georgetown University, Washington, District of Columbia, as well as a diploma from the Naval War College in Newport, Rhode Island.

Whitworth’s command tours included commander, Joint Intelligence Center Central; commanding officer, Navy Element of U.S. Central Command; and commanding officer, Kennedy Irregular Warfare Center.

Whitworth’s operational tours included director of Intelligence for The Joint Staff, director of Intelligence for U.S. Africa Command, director of Intelligence for Joint Special Operations Command, director of Intelligence and deputy director of Maritime Operations Center for Commander, U.S. Naval Forces Central Command, U.S. Fifth Fleet; director of Intelligence for a Special Operations Task Force in Afghanistan during three deployments supporting Operation Enduring Freedom; director of Intelligence for Naval Special Warfare Development Group; special assistant for Political-Military Affairs at U.S. Sixth Fleet during Operation Allied Force; indications and warning officer at U.S. Naval Forces Central Command, U.S. Fifth Fleet, in support of Operation Desert Storm; and intelligence officer for Fighter squadron 31 during USS Forrestal’s deployment in support of Operation Provide Comfort.

Whitworth’s shore-based tours included the National Security Agency, chief of targets for the U.S. Central Command area of responsibility; Navy federal executive fellow to American Enterprise Institute; senior duty officer at the White House Situation Room; intelligence briefer for the Chief of Naval Operations and Secretary of the Navy; and intelligence watch analyst at the Office of Naval Intelligence and the National Military Joint Intelligence Center.

Whitworth is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. Some of his decorations include the Defense Superior Service Medal, Legion of Merit, Bronze Star, Defense Meritorious Service Medal, as well as the Edwin T. Layton Leadership Award, Vice Admiral Rufus L. Taylor Leadership Award, the Army’s Knowlton Award for excellence in intelligence.

name: Mr. Matt Higgins
title: Co-Founder & CEO
bio:
Matt Higgins is a noted serial entrepreneur, growth equity investor as Co-founder and CEO of private investment firm, RSE Ventures, and Wall Street Journal best-selling author of Burn The Boats.

He is also an Executive Fellow at the Harvard Business School where he co-teaches the course “Moving Beyond Direct-to-Consumer.”  Mr. Higgins’ deep operating experience spans multiple industries over his 25-year career, which he draws upon to help founders navigate complex situations in order to reach their full potential.

Mr. Higgins began his career in public service as a journalist before becoming the youngest mayoral press secretary in New York City at 26, where he managed the global media response to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks. He became one of the first employees – and ultimately Chief Operating Officer – of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the federally funded government agency created to plan the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. Mr. Higgins helped organize the largest international design competition in history culminating in Reflecting Absence, the September 11th National Memorial, and the development of the 1,776-feet-tall One World Trade Center, the tallest building in the northern hemisphere.

After transitioning to the private sector, Mr. Higgins spent 15 years in senior leadership positions with National Football League teams. He made his mark with two NFL franchises, overseeing the revenue functions of the New York Jets as Executive Vice President of Business Operations, and after leaving the Jets, serving as Vice Chairman of the Miami Dolphins from 2012 – 2021. Higgins co-founded New York City-based RSE Ventures in 2012, amassing a multi-billion-dollar investment portfolio of leading brands across sports and entertainment, media and marketing, consumer and technology industries – including several of Fast Company’s Most Innovative Companies.

name: Mr. John Ridge CBE
title: Chief Adoption Officer
bio:
After completing his Architectural Engineering degree in 1995, John joined the Royal Engineers. He completed tours with Commandos and Gurkhas, deploying to Northern Ireland, Norway, Oman, Kosovo and Bosnia. He later commanded a bomb disposal squadron and a close support engineer regiment, including three tours of Helmand Province, Afghanistan. His staff tours included two years as a Military Assistant, a tour developing the UK's offensive counter-IED strategy and time as the Army Pay Colonel. After attending Higher Command and Staff Course (HCSC), he took command of 8 Engineer Brigade, after which he was appointed Chief of Joint Force Operations, a tour which included deploying as the Joint Task Force Commander for the UK's crisis response to Hurricanes Irma and Maria.

John left the Army in 2020 to join the Civil Service. He spent two years as Director Strategy and Enterprise Services in Defence Intelligence where he led transformation and corporate services. In March 2022, he moved to 10 Downing Street on a six-month loan, leading transformation and working as part of a broader Cabinet Office change programme. He returned to MOD in September 2022 as Director Defence Innovation where he led Defence's innovation portfolio, including being the UK representative on the NATO DIANA Board of Directors and leading the Innovation Working Group in AUKUS Pillar 2. After just over two years in this post, John left government for the first time to join the NATO Innovation Fund as their first Chief Adoption Officer.

name: Dr. Steven A. Smith
title: Director Special Programs (Aviation); U.S. Army Aviation and Missile Command
company: Program Executive Officer Rotary Wing, U.S. Special Operations Command

name: Colonel Mark Cleary
title: Project Manager, Technology Applications Program Office
bio:
COL Mark Cleary was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in 2003 in the U.S. Army Aviation branch. He earned a Bachelor of Science in Aerospace Engineering from Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University and began his career at Fort Rucker with the 1st Battalion, 145th Aviation Regiment. His first operational assignment was flying OH-58D Kiowa Warrior helicopters in the 1st Battalion, 82nd Aviation Brigade, later reflagged as the 1st Squadron, 17th Cavalry Regiment, where he served as a Platoon Leader and Assistant Operations Officer, deploying in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom.

After completing the Aviation Captain’s Career Course, COL Cleary was selected for the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment (SOAR) (Airborne). He completed SERE training, the CH-47D Chinook qualification course, and MH-47G Officer Green Platoon before joining the 3rd Battalion, 160th SOAR (A) as a Platoon Leader. He conducted multiple deployments in Operation Enduring Freedom as a Fully Mission Qualified Pilot in Command and Officer in Charge. He later commanded Company B, 1st Battalion, 228th Aviation Regiment at Soto Cano Airbase, Honduras.

Following command, he attended Army Acquisition Courses, the Fixed Wing Multi-Engine Qualification Course, U.S. Naval Test Pilot School, and Command and General Staff College.
